intro: Lippia felippei, commonly known as Mexican mint or wild mint, is a perennial herb native to Central America and parts of the southern United States. It belongs to the Verbenaceae family and is characterized by its aromatic, slightly minty scent. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, ovate to lanceolate leaves that are hairy on the underside. It produces small, tubular flowers in clusters, usually white or pale purple, which bloom in the summer months. Lippia felippei is often used in traditional medicine and as a culinary herb due to its aromatic properties.
